questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of hyperthyroidism is diagnosed with a brain tumor and is scheduled for neurosurgery. Thiopentone has been chosen as the induction agent for this surgery. Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Thiopentone?

options.label: A
options.text: Thiopentone decreases intracranial pressure, making it suitable for neurosurgical procedures

options.label: B
options.text: Porphyria is a relative contraindication for thiopentone

options.label: C
options.text: The mechanism for termination of action is by redistribution from brain to fat cells

options.label: D
options.text: Thiopentone has antithyroid properties and thus is an agent of choice for hyperthyroid patients

questions.correct_answer: B. Porphyria is a relative contraindication for thiopentone
questions.explanation:
Absolute

Relative
  • Porphyria
  • Heart Blocks
  • Hypotension
  • Asthma

Mechanism of Termination

Redistribution from the brain to fat and muscle tissues

Metabolism

Metabolised in the liver by hydroxylation

Excretion

Excreted by the kidneys

questions.text: A 45 year old male undergoes a minor surgical procedure for lipoma excision under local anesthesia with bupivacaine. Shortly after administration, he complains of tinnitus, dizziness and a metallic taste in his mouth. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Toxicity
  • Lipophilic nature leads to slow dissociation/prolonged blocking from cardiac sodium channels.
  • Persistent channel blockage causes cumulative cardiotoxicity.

Symptoms
  • CNS: Tinnitus, metallic taste, dizziness, seizures.
  • Cardiovascular: Bradycardia, dysrhythmias, asystole.

Treatment
  • 20% lipid emulsion therapy acts as a "lipid sink" to reduce tissue concentration of bupivacaine.
  • Effective airway management is vital, especially in the presence of acidosis, hypercarbia, or hypoxemia.

Exacerbating Factors

Acidosis, hypercarbia, hypoxemia can worsen cardiac toxicity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of chronic kidney disease and liver cirrhosis is scheduled for elective abdominal surgery. The anesthesiologist must choose an appropriate muscle relaxant for intubation and intraoperative muscle relaxation. Considering the patient's comorbidities, the anesthesiologist is evaluating the use of cisatracurium instead of atracurium. Which of the following statements is true regarding Atracurium?

options.label: C
options.text: Preferred muscle relaxant in liver/ kidney disease

questions.explanation:
Atracurium

Cisatracurium
  1. Mixture of >10 isomers
  2. Metabolized by Hoffmann elimination and plasma esterase
  3. Dose-dependent histamine release ➞ allergy (Option B)
  4. Should be avoided in patients with kidney/ liver disease, as its toxic metabolite laudanosine gets accumulated ➞ CNS toxicity ➞ seizures
  1. Made of one isomer (Option D)
  2. 100% of the drug is metabolized by Hofmann elimination (Option A)
  3. No histamine release
  4. Safe in patients with kidney/ liver disease (Option C).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department for an urgent intubation due to respiratory failure. The anesthesiologist decides to use succinylcholine to facilitate rapid sequence intubation. Which of the following statements is false regarding succinylcholine?

options.label: D
options.text: Drug of choice in stroke and hemiplegia

questions.correct_answer: D. Drug of choice in stroke and hemiplegia
questions.explanation:
Toxicity of succinylcholine:
  • Diaphragm paralysis ➞ Scoline apnea (Option A)
  • Hyperkalemia (Option B)
    • Due to potassium release ➞ cardiac arrest
    • Increased in trauma, burns, rhabdomyolysis
  • Malignant hyperthermia
    • Treated by Dantrolene
  • Histamine release
  • SA node partial agonist leads to bradycardia , junctional rhythm - treatment: i/v atropine

Contraindications:
  • Muscle dystrophy (Option C)
  • Neurological disease
    • Hemiplegia
    • Stroke (Option D)
  • Contraindicated in head injury, glaucoma
    • Increases ICP, IOP

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoing elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy develops muscle fasciculations followed by flaccid paralysis after a neuromuscular blocking agent is administered. Despite neostigmine administration, the muscle relaxation persists. Which muscle relaxant was administered?
questions.explanation:
Depolarizing Blockers

Non-Depolarizing Blockers

Drugs

Suxamethonium/ succinylcholine

Curonium, curium, curare

MOA

Phase1

 
  • Opening of Nm receptor (like Ach)
    • Initial muscle contraction- fasciculation
    • Depolarizing SMR
 

Enters into phase 2

  • Desensitization of the Nm receptor ➞ flaccid paralysis of the muscle

Competitively block Nm receptor of Ach

  • They are non-depolarizing and cause flaccid paralysis

Role of

Neostigmine

Neostigmine cannot reverse the effect

of succinylcholine

For reversal of NDMR:

increase Ach

o Neostigmine

o Edrophonium

Initial

Fasciculations

Present

Absent

Postoperative

myalgia

Present

Absent

Cold Temperature

Increase the effect

Decrease the effect

Muscle sensitivity

1st to paralyze: Neck muscle

Last to paralyze: Diaphragm

(Most resistant, 1st to recover)

1st: Fingers

Last: Diaphragm

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetics is used to diagnose pseudocholinesterase deficiency?

In the context of differential sensitivity of nerve fibers to local anaesthetics, which of the following sequences correctly represents the order in which different types of nerve fibres are blocked, starting from the most sensitive to the least sensitive?

options.label: A
options.text: Type A alpha, Type A beta, Type A gamma, Type A delta, Type C

options.label: B
options.text: Type A delta, Type A gamma, Type A beta, Type A alpha,Type C

options.label: C
options.text: Type A delta, Type A alpha, Type A beta, Type A gamma, Type C

options.label: D
options.text: Type C, Type A gamma, Type A delta, Type A beta, Type A alpha

questions.correct_answer: B. Type A delta, Type A gamma, Type A beta, Type A alpha,Type C

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient was sedated for more than 48 hours following status epilepticus. He developed refractory bradycardia, hyperlipidemia, and renal failure. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis showed metabolic acidosis. Which of the following sedatives is most likely responsible for these symptoms?

A 40-year-old patient is administered an intermediate-acting amide as a local anesthetic during a minor surgical procedure on the upper extremity. Shortly after administration, the patient develops cyanosis and complains of shortness of breath. Which of the following is most likely the local anesthetic based on the above symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Duration of Action

Local Anaesthetic

Ultra Short

Chloroprocaine (shortest)

Short

Procaine

Intermediate

Lidocaine, Prilocaine, Mepivacaine

Long

Bupivacaine, Ropivacaine, Etidocaine, Tetracaine, Dibucaine (longest)

 

Amides

Esters

Physical property

Stable solution

Unstable, structurally                            similar to PABA.

Metabolism

By liver

Esterase enzyme

Exceptions

Artikane by esterase

Cocaine in liver

Examples

Prilocaine, lignocaine

Procaine

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the preoperative evaluation, the anesthesiologist explains the different types of anaesthetics that will be used and points at a cylinder having a blue body and white shoulder, along with a fast-acting IV drug. What are these anaesthetic agents?
questions.explanation:
Gas

Colour Coding

 Pin Index    Safety System

Air

Grey body + black/white shoulder

1,5

Oxygen

Black body + white shoulder

2,5

Nitrous Oxide

Blue

3,5

Entonox (Nitrous Oxide + Oxygen) (Option A)

Blue body + white shoulder

7

Carbon Dioxide (>7.5%)

Grey

1,6

Carbon Dioxide (<7.5%)

Grey

2,6

Cyclopropane

Orange

3,6

questions.text: Which of the following statements about isoflurane is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Isoflurane primarily causes a drop in blood pressure through cardiac depression

options.label: B
options.text: Isoflurane maintains cardiac output while causing vasodilation

options.label: C
options.text: Isoflurane is known to provoke seizures, making it unsuitable for patients undergoing neurosurgery

options.label: D
options.text: Isoflurane causes significant metabolic byproducts, leading to renal and hepatic toxicity.

questions.correct_answer: B. Isoflurane maintains cardiac output while causing vasodilation
questions.explanation:
System

Effects

CVS
  • Decrease in BP - due to vasodilation (Option A)
  • CO is well maintained - suitable for patients with myocardial insufficiency (Option B)
  • HR is increased due to reflex tachycardia
  • Dilates coronaries - possibility of coronary steal syndrome

RS
  • Respiratory depression
  • Increased secretions

Uterus and Skeletal Muscles

Muscle Relaxation

Ocular

Pupils do not dilate and light reflex is not lost.

Metabolism

Negligible - No renal or hepatotoxicity

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of asthma presents to the operating room for elective surgery. Halothane is used as the primary anaesthetic agent. During the induction phase, the patient suddenly develops ventricular arrhythmias. What is the most likely mechanism underlying the ventricular arrhythmias induced by halothane in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Sensitization of the myocardium to catecholamines

options.label: D
options.text: Potentiation of calcium influx into cardiac myocytes

questions.correct_answer: C. Sensitization of the myocardium to catecholamines
questions.explanation:
System

Effects

CVS
  • Decrease in BP due to cardiac depression
  • CO is reduced with deepening anesthesia
  • HR is reduced
  • Sensitize the heart to the arrhythmogenic action of adrenaline/noradrenaline

RS
  • Respiratory depression
  • Bronchodilation - DOC for asthmatics

GI/GU

Inhibits intestinal and uterine contractions

↓BP → ↓GFR → ↓ urine formation

Metabolism

By liver - Hepatotoxic

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing surgery for an abdominal hernia repair. Cyclopropane is chosen as the anaesthetic agent. During the procedure, electrocautery is used to control bleeding. Due to concerns about cyclopropane's high flammability, the anesthesiologist decides to discontinue its administration. The patient experiences a drop in blood pressure. What is the most likely cause of the patient's hypotension?

options.label: A
options.text: An equipment malfunction resulted in inadequate delivery of oxygen during surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Sudden withdrawal of cyclopropane led to a sharp decrease in sympathetic nervous system activity

options.label: C
options.text: The patient experienced a common side effect of the electrocautery

options.label: D
options.text: The patient had an allergic reaction to cyclopropane

questions.correct_answer: B. Sudden withdrawal of cyclopropane led to a sharp decrease in sympathetic nervous system activity

questions.text: Entonox, used for analgesia during painful procedures, exhibits the Poynting effect. Which of the following statements best describes the Poynting effect in Entonox?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the individual properties of nitrogen and oxygen to intensify when combined

options.label: B
options.text: It results in the production of a gas mixture that behaves differently from its individual components

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the likelihood of adverse effects when administering Entonox

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to the rapid separation of nitrogen and oxygen at high pressures

questions.correct_answer: B. It results in the production of a gas mixture that behaves differently from its individual components

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of substance abuse presents for a wisdom tooth extraction. The patient is known to abuse nitrous oxide recreationally. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The anesthesiologist is considering the use of nitrous oxide for sedation. Which of the following complications should the anesthesiologist be most concerned about for this patient?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the left side, and chest X-ray confirms left-sided pneumothorax. The patient is scheduled for an urgent chest tube insertion under general anaesthesia. Which of the following inhaled anaesthetics is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Inhaled Anaesthetic

Effect on Air Spaces

Use in Pneumothorax

Nitrous oxide

Expands air-filled cavities

Contraindicated

Sevoflurane (Option A ruled out)

No significant effect

Safe

Isoflurane (Option B ruled out)

No significant effect

Safe

Desflurane (Option D ruled out)

No significant effect

Safe

questions.text: Match each inhalation agent with its corresponding blood/gas partition coefficient: Inhaled anaesthetic B/G partition coefficient a) Sevoflurane 1) 0.47 b) Isoflurane 2) 0.68 c) Desflurane 3) 1.4 d) Nitrous oxide 4) 0.42
questions.explanation:
B/G Partition Coefficient

Inhalation anaesthetic

Lowest

Desflurane (Fastest acting)- 0.42

Highest

Ether (Slowest acting)- 12.1

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute onset right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, he has right lower quadrant rebound tenderness and guarding. The doctor decides to take him up for an emergency surgery. Which inhalation anaesthetic would be best for induction in this patient based on its MAC values and blood gas solubility?
questions.explanation:
MAC Value

Inhalation anaesthetic

Lowest

Halothane (Most potent) -0.75

Highest

Nitrous oxide (Least potent) -105
